thread.title: Hopes for Tunisia as Thomas Cook keeps winter programme on sale

title: Hopes for Tunisia as Thomas Cook keeps winter programme on sale
text:
Save 
Thomas Cook has insisted it “still believes” in Tunisia, and that its winter programme to the country remains on sale. 
It comes after foreign secretary Philip Hammond hinted this week that the UK Foreign Office could lift its advice against all but essential travel to Tunisia in time for the winter season. 
The Daily Telegraph reported that foreign secretary Philip Hammond had met with the Tunisian prime minister Habid Essid to discuss how the EU could help the struggling country, following the devastating terror attack which killed 30 Britons last month. 
Hammond reportedly told Essid that the current FCO ban against all but essential travel to the country could be lifted within “weeks, certainly months” providing the country was able to show it was making progress in hunting down the terrorist network responsible for the massacre of 38 tourists in Sousse. 
The news followed the release of a statement from Jet2.com and Jet2holidays, which revealed that the company had stopped selling flights and holidays to Tunisia for the remainder of 2015 as well as summer 2016. 
However Thomas Cook commercial director Chris Mottershead told TTG the travel giant “still believed” in Tunisia, and that its winter programme to the country remained on sale. 
“It is a very important market for Thomas Cook,” he said. “We have to watch advice from the FCO [but] the [winter] programme [from November 1 onwards] is on sale and we believe the advice will change in time based on previous decisions. 
“We are hoping and anticipating the FCO advice will change.” 
The operator originally had 37 flights a week across Europe to the destination, but Mottershead said many of these had been diverted in the wake of the current situation. 
“Customers still want to travel, we had a very high number of [Tunisia] customers rebook. We did everything to match the holidays they were looking for.”
